Hi Oliver, congrats on your first publication.  It's great to have such a=
 comprehensive review of the subject.  Of course the area also has a lot of=
 potential and your paper helps to point the way forward.

I also wanted to=
 mention a paper relevant to this subject that I published recently with An=
drea Soltoggio, based on work he did in part when he was visiting our lab h=
ere at UCF.  The paper, titled "From Modulated Hebbian Plasticity to Simple=
 Behavior Learning through Noise and Weight Saturation," is available here:=


http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2012/soltoggio-nn12

It's important =
to note that the paper has no evolution - all the experiments are done with=
 small networks that learn entirely from their plasticity rules from scratc=
h.  However, I think the unique new plasticity mechanisms that are introduc=
ed can probably provoke a lot of interesting new directions for neuroevolve=
d networks.  Part of its story also goes against conventional wisdom:  It s=
hows how neural noise can be an asset and that weight saturation, which is =
often seen as a problem in Hebbian learning, can be turned into an advantag=
e.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Oliver Coleman <oliver.coleman@...>=
 wrote:
>
> I'm proud to announce my first paper produced as part of my PhD=
 will
> be presented at the 25th Australian Joint Conference on Artificial
=
> Intelligence, 4-7 December 2012.
> 
> Title: Evolving Plastic Neural Netw=
orks for Online Learning: Review
> and Future Directions
> Authors: Oliver =
J. Coleman, Alan D. Blair
> 
> Abstract:
> Recent years have seen a resurge=
nce of interest in evolving plastic
> neural networks for online learning. =
These approaches have an
> intrinsic appeal =96 since, to date, the only wo=
rking example of general
> intelligence is the human brain, which has devel=
oped through
> evolution, and exhibits a great capacity to adapt to unfamil=
iar
> environments. In this paper we review prior work in this area =96
> i=
ncluding problem domains and tasks, fitness functions, synaptic
> plasticit=
y models and neural network encoding schemes. We conclude
> with a discussi=
on of current findings and promising future directions,
> including incorpo=
ration of functional properties observed in
> biological neural networks wh=
ich appear to play a role in learning
> processes, and addressing the "gene=
ral" in general intelligence by the
> introduction of previously unseen tas=
ks during the evolution process.
> 
> The full paper is available at
> http=
://ojcoleman.com/sites/default/files/files/ojcoleman_ajcai2012_evolving_pla=
stic_neural_networks_for_online_learning_review_and_future_directions.pdf
>=
